posts.com:
Hey /g/

Back in the 1980s and 1990s, the Japanese made quality stuff. Honda, Toyota, Suzuki, Yamaha, Panasonic, Sony, Mitsubushi. If you bought Japanese, you were buying quality and importantly, reliablity. Back then Koreans made Chinese-tier quality shit.

Now since the 2000s S. Korea has been rising in both automotion and tech. Samsung, LG, Hyundai, Kia, and the Japanese seem to be placing less emphasis on reliabiltiy (e.g Sony products have a short life cycle, Toshiba don't even honour the warranty on their HDDs)

Do you think the Koreans have overtaken the Japanese in exports? I'm not talking raw data, just a general feeling you get about how it's developing. They're certainly in competition with each other.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>37624077
Japans economy sucked ass during the '90s
for the longest time, the biggest companies in Japan were international companies, and Nintendo was literally Japans wealthiest tech company during that era (and for much of the 2000s as well)

posts.com:
>>37617688
s = 'azcbobobegghakl'

def LongestSubstring(s):
    current = [0]
    list_of_strings = []
    for x in [ord(x) for x in s]:
        if x >= current[-1]:
            current.append(x)
        else:
            list_of_strings.append(current)
            del current[0]
            current = [0]
            current.append(x)
    list_of_strings.append(current[1:])
    print ''.join(map(lambda x: chr(x), max(list_of_strings, key=lambda x: len(x))))
.
